title: Sergei Semak
text:
Sergei Bogdanovich Semak ( ; ; born 27 February 1976) is a Russian <a href="Association%20football">football</a> manager and a former <a href="Russia%20national%20football%20team">international</a> <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a> who currently manages <a href="Russian%20Premier%20League">Russian Premier League</a> side <a href="FC%20Zenit%20Saint%20Petersburg">FC Zenit</a>.
Early life.
Semak was born in the <a href="village">selo</a> <a href="Sychanske">Sychanskoye</a> in the <a href="Luhansk%20Oblast">Voroshilovgradskaya Oblast</a> into a peasant family of modest economical background. He was an excellent student and had an ideal behavior. When he was a child his teachers would argue as to whether he would become a mathematician or a football player.
He left Ukraine shortly before the <a href="USSR">USSR</a> fall, but his parents stayed there. He would become a Russian naturalized citizen, but until today he uses to visit his bornland; he had declared that he misses Ukraine.
His older brother <a href="Andrei%20Semak">Andrei Semak</a> and younger brother Nikolai Semak were also professional footballers.
Club career.
He started training football at the Luhansk football school.
In 1992, he signed in <a href="FC%20Presnya%20Moscow">FC Presnya Moscow</a> who played in the <a href="Russian%20Top%20Division">Russian Top Division</a>. After 19 matches (where he scored 4 goals) he was sold to <a href="FC%20Karelia%20Petrozavodsk">FC Karelia Petrozavodsk</a>, but in 1993 returned to <a href="FC%20Presnya%20Moscow">FC Presnya Moscow</a> (which changed its name to <a href="Asmaral%20Moscow">Asmaral Moscow</a>).
In 1994, he was noted and signed by <a href="PFC%20CSKA%20Moscow">PFC CSKA Moscow</a>. He became the club's captain and leader. With the club he won the <a href="Russian%20Premier%20League">Russian Premier League</a> in 2003, the <a href="Russian%20Cup%20%28football%29">Russian Cup</a> in 2002 and 2005. He left the club after it finished third in the group stage of the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League%202004%E2%80%9305">UEFA Champions League 2004–05</a> and did not move on to the knockout stage.
In 2005, he moved to <a href="Paris%20Saint-Germain%20FC">Paris Saint-Germain FC</a>, France, but failed to settle, scoring just one goal. After just one season he returned to <a href="Russia">Russia</a>.
In 2006, he signed for <a href="FC%20Moscow">FC Moscow</a>, where he stayed until 2008 when he moved to <a href="Rubin%20Kazan">Rubin Kazan</a>. In Rubin Semak was moved from the positions of striker and attacking midfielder to the position of a defensive midfielder.
In <a href="Rubin%20Kazan">Rubin</a> he became the captain and leader of the team, and led it to its first two championship titles in 2008 and 2009.
In August 2010, he transferred to <a href="FC%20Zenit%20Saint%20Petersburg">FC Zenit St. Petersburg</a>.
International career.
Semak made his international debut in 1997 and took part in the <a href="2002%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2002 FIFA World Cup</a> in South Korea and Japan.
Having lost his place in the national team with the arrival of <a href="Guus%20Hiddink">Guus Hiddink</a> in 2006, Semak missed out on Russia's <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202008%20qualifying">Euro 2008 qualifying campaign</a>, but was recalled to the national team, just prior to the <a href="Euro%202008">Euro 2008</a> finals. Semak captained the Russia national team in their first Euro 2008 warm-up friendly against <a href="Kazakhstan%20national%20football%20team">Kazakhstan</a>, and during the rest of the campaign.
Sergei Semak had a good performance in the crucial match against <a href="Greece%20national%20football%20team">Greece</a> and provided an assist for the only goal Russia scored with a skilled bicycle kick pass from a wide angle. Another notable performance in <a href="Euro%202008">Euro 2008</a> came in the quarter-finals during which he was playing his 50th game for his country, when his precise left-wing cross was volleyed in by <a href="Roman%20Pavlyuchenko">Roman Pavlyuchenko</a> against the <a href="Netherlands%20national%20football%20team">Netherlands</a>.
Managerial career.
After his retirement, Semak was named as assistant coach of <a href="Zenit%20Saint%20Petersburg">Zenit Saint Petersburg</a>. He was appointed interim coach of the club after the sacking of <a href="Luciano%20Spalletti">Luciano Spalletti</a> on 10 March 2014. He held the position until 18 March when <a href="Andr%C3%A9%20Villas-Boas">André Villas-Boas</a> was appointed as the team manager.
On 30 December 2016, he was appointed a manager of the <a href="Russian%20Premier%20League">Russian Premier League</a> club <a href="FC%20Ufa">FC Ufa</a>.
On 29 May 2018, he returned to <a href="FC%20Zenit%20Saint%20Petersburg">Zenit St. Petersburg</a>, signing a 2-year contract with 1-year extension option. In his first year, he won the <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20Russian%20Premier%20League">2018–19 Russian Premier League</a>. He led Zenit to the title again in the <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20Russian%20Premier%20League">2019–20 Russian Premier League</a>. On 25 July 2020, he sealed the double for the club by winning the <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20Russian%20Cup">2019–20 Russian Cup</a>. On 2 May 2021, Zenit secured their third title in a row in a 6-1 victory over second-place <a href="FC%20Lokomotiv%20Moscow">FC Lokomotiv Moscow</a>.
Honours.
Club.
CSKA Moscow 
Paris Saint-Germain 
Rubin Kazan 
Zenit 
International.
Russia 
Manager.
Zenit
Individual
